alert.note: Alert for Greater Portland Metro Area; Lower Columbia; Western Columbia River Gorge (Oregon) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Portland (Northwest Oregon and Southwest Washington)
info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued April 11 at 3:44AM PDT by NWS Portland
info.description: ...LIGHT SNOW FOR THE HIGHEST ELEVATIONS WEDNESDAY MORNING ACROSS THE PORTLAND/VANCOUVER METRO, LOWER COLUMBIA/COWLITZ I-5 CORRIDOR, AND THE WESTERN GORGE... A cold upper low pressure center will cross far northwest Oregon and far southwest Washington Tuesday night and Wednesday morning. This low pressure area will swing a cold front across the region Tuesday night leaving showers in its wake. Most areas and elevations will see snowflakes mix in with the rain showers Wednesday morning with little to no accumulations or impacts. However for elevations near and above 1000 feet, snow will be the more dominant precipitation type. Some areas near and above 1000 feet may see around one-half inch of snow accumulation during the Wednesday morning commute hours. Most areas will not see much, if any, impact. Any snow accumulation is expected to be short-lived with significant melting occurring by 10 AM Wednesday with temperatures warming above 40 degrees. Plan on the Wednesday morning commute to take longer than normal for those living in areas where light snow accumulations do occur.

area.areaDesc: Greater Portland Metro Area; Lower Columbia; Western Columbia River Gorge
